uh our the software that we use to be the thing that that we imagine

bunch of people but we can only create so much for you and at some point you want to take over
and extend our platform and that's something that's really
important to us to be able to allow because again we're developers we understand that this is a thing that that is
important to you and that it's important to the ecosystem to allow and so one of the
things that we've always been proud of is the way that we allow you to extend our platform
so the first way that we did this was with what we call github apps so we've had a piece of functionality
called web hooks that we've built into the github platform from the beginning and a web hook is basically just
something that will call your application when something on github happens for example when somebody opens a pull
request you can register to have a web hook that is delivered every time somebody opens a pull request
or every time somebody comments on an issue and so github will just like open a
a tcp port to your whatever you specify and send you an http payload with the
issue comment that was delivered right and so from there you can build automation around this
every time somebody comments on an issue you can you can actually perform an action
and and do something and send back a response so you can authenticate to github and
you can do you can do something and by gluing these
this technology around web hooks you can extend the github platform you can
um you can basically assign a new issue to somebody as soon as somebody opens an issue in your
in your project right you can you can look at maybe some details and assign it
to a first responder for example um so that it gets triaged um you can add labels to it
and those sorts of things and so you can start to automate uh tools around your repository and
basically extend the github platform to do what it is that that you want to do and that's very very cool
this was our first attempt at allowing you to extend the platform but it has a problem and that problem is
that you have to bring that that computer along right this is not uh something that that just
happens for free you need to provision a machine you need to um you know whether that's
in the cloud or even you know inside your data center something under your desk
you have to bring the machine along and that means you need to you're responsible for for its
maintenance and and paying for it and that's not ideal that's actually not the
way that we want you to to have to extend our platform we want to allow you to extend the platform
but we also want to allow you to do it uh in a cost effective way
and so the idea behind github actions is that we take all that
knowledge out of github apps and we host it for you this was at least the original idea
behind behind github actions the idea is that we will bring the compute so now
every time a event occurs inside your repository instead of just firing a web
hook now you can configure something that runs within the github actions platform
and so you can now take that issue comment and perform a response now
we started github actions in in beta almost two years ago about a year and a
half and the way that we did this was that we gave you um the ability to run docker
containers every time something happened in your in your repository so every time an issue comment happened
we would run a docker container that you specified and that was was really really cool it
was really really powerful because now you could take that custom logic that you would have put into a github
app previously and just dockerize it and now we'll run it for you inside our
infrastructure we'll take care of all of the execution and we'll pay for it
now this was great we were really excited about this we launched it as a veda and
immediately our customers started doing really cool things like triaging issues every time um every time
a new issue was opened or issue was commented on something like that and they would start
automating things around pull requests and what we hadn't thought of but it
turned out our customers did was the um the immediate thing that people started to do around
automating pull requests was running a build and running tests
now this probably should have been obvious to us but it wasn't we weren't building a ci platform we were building an extension
on top of github but our customers what they wanted to extend was ci and so we we hit
pause for a second because we really hadn't built ci platform we hadn't built something that could
really um take care of most most people's
applications if you had a simple node app you know we could run your tests in a docker container no problem
but if you were building a net app on windows if you were building an ios app you need to run an ios app on
macintosh that's part of apple's license you can only build it and run tests there so we actually hit
pause on our beta we re-thought github actions and we came back with something that kept the spirit
of being able to extend the github platform but we allowed you to instead of just
running in a docker container we gave you real virtual machines in our cloud so um so today
github actions uh allows you to extend the platform but it also allows you to run uh ci we've
